unnormalised: So, you’re planning a trip, eh? Excellent! Prepare yourself for the joys of booking, because that’s where the fun *really* starts. First, you’ll need a PNR number. Not to be confused with paneer, although that would be far tastier. This magical, often indecipherable code, like Z7X9CV, is your key to...well, knowing if you're actually going anywhere. Treat it like gold; lose it, and you might as well be shouting your travel plans into the void.
normalised: So, you’re planning a trip, eh? Excellent! Prepare yourself for the joys of booking, because that’s where the fun *really* starts. First, you’ll need a P-N-R number. Not to be confused with paneer, although that would be far tastier. This magical, often indecipherable code, like Z seven X nine C V, is your key to...well, knowing if you're actually going anywhere. Treat it like gold; lose it, and you might as well be shouting your travel plans into the void.

unnormalised: Then there’s the ticket number. Oh, the ticket number! A string of digits so long, like 098-7654321, it feels like pi decided to take a holiday on your boarding pass. This is what the airline *thinks* proves you paid for your privilege of being crammed into a metal tube hurtling through the sky. Keep this number safe. It’s also crucial if you need a refund because the airline "lost" your luggage (more on that later).
normalised: Then there’s the ticket number. Oh, the ticket number! A string of digits so long, like zero nine eight dash seven six five four three two one, it feels like pi decided to take a holiday on your boarding pass. This is what the airline *thinks* proves you paid for your privilege of being crammed into a metal tube hurtling through the sky. Keep this number safe. It’s also crucial if you need a refund because the airline "lost" your luggage (more on that later).

unnormalised: And don’t even get me STARTED on the frequent flyer ID, which airlines make sound so glamorous. It’s really just a fancy way of saying, "We know you're a glutton for punishment, so here's some points that might, possibly, maybe get you a free bag of peanuts in 20 years." Mine is something like AB12345678, which I only remember by chanting it backward while patting my head and rubbing my stomach. Try it; it's a great party trick.
normalised: And don’t even get me STARTED on the frequent flyer I-D, which airlines make sound so glamorous. It’s really just a fancy way of saying, "We know you're a glutton for punishment, so here's some points that might, possibly, maybe get you a free bag of peanuts in twenty years." Mine is something like A B one two three four five six seven eight, which I only remember by chanting it backward while patting my head and rubbing my stomach. Try it; it's a great party trick.

unnormalised: But wait, there's more! You also have booking references. Airline booking references are usually 6-character alphanumeric codes, e.g., "H2XY9Z." Tour operators, on the other hand, might have a different format altogether. Let's say you book a trip via "India Holiday Experts"; your booking reference may be something like "IHE/2024/00789." The sheer variety keeps things interesting, doesn't it?
normalised: But wait, there's more! You also have booking references. Airline booking references are usually six character alphanumeric codes, e.g., "H two X Y nine Z." Tour operators, on the other hand, might have a different format altogether. Let's say you book a trip via "India Holiday Experts"; your booking reference may be something like "I-H-E slash two thousand and twenty four slash zero zero seven eight nine." The sheer variety keeps things interesting, doesn't it?

unnormalised: So, there you have it: a crash course in travel identifier madness. Remember to keep all these numbers safe, and maybe even memorize them. Or, you know, just take a screenshot and pray your phone doesn't die. Happy travels! May your flights be on time, your luggage arrive intact, and your sanity remain (mostly) undisturbed.
normalised: So, there you have it: a crash course in travel identifier madness. Remember to keep all these numbers safe, and maybe even memorize them. Or, you know, just take a screenshot and pray your phone doesn't die. Happy travels! May your flights be on time, your luggage arrive intact, and your sanity remain (mostly) undisturbed.
